content.text: A box of cereal costs \(\$ 2.29\).
Work out the maximum number of boxes of cereal that Li can buy.
(ii) Each box of cereal has mass 615 g .
Work out the total mass of 5 boxes of cereal. Give your answer in kilograms.
(iii) The box of cereal is a cuboid.
The cuboid measures 25 cm by 20 cm by 5 cm .
Work out the volume of the cuboid.
(b) A cereal bar is in a box.
The box is a cuboid measuring 6 cm by 3 cm by 1 cm .
On the \(1 \mathrm{~cm}^{2}\) grid, complete a net of the cuboid.
One face has been drawn for you.
(i) Work out the percentage of the mass of the cereal that is fat.
(ii) \(60 \%\) of the mass of the cereal is carbohydrate. Complete the pie chart.
(iii) Work out the mass of protein in 30 g of the cereal.
(c) The cereal contains fat, protein, carbohydrate and fibre. The pie chart shows the information about the masses of fat and protein.
2 (a) Write the number 845 024 in words.
(b) Write these numbers in order, starting with the smallest.
smallest
(iii) \(\sqrt{16} \times \sqrt{49}\).
(c) Find the value of
(d) Solve.
(e) By writing each number in the calculation correct to 1 significant figure, find an estimate for the value of
You must show all your working.
Find the value of \(x\).
(g) Simplify \(\left(x^{4}\right)^{3}\).
(h) A boat to town \(A\) leaves a port every 16 minutes.
A boat to town \(B\) leaves the same port every 34 minutes.
Both boats leave the port at 07.30.
Work out the next time both boats leave the port together.
A wedding invitation is in the shape of a rectangle.
Draw the lines of symmetry on this rectangle.
(b) There are 98 adults and 56 children at the wedding.
Find the fraction of people who are children.
Give your fraction in its simplest form.
(c) The wedding meal starts at 13 15 and lasts for 2 hours 50 minutes.
Find the time the meal ends.
(d) The probability that it will rain at the wedding is 0.12 .
Find the probability that it will not rain.
(e) (i) These are the ages of the staff at the wedding.
Complete the stem-and-leaf diagram.
Key: \(1|6\) represents 16
(ii) Find the range.
Find the value of \(r\) when \(n=180\) and \(c=3\).
(b) Factorise completely.
(c) Apples cost 35 cents each and bananas cost 14 cents each.
Write down an expression for the total cost, in cents, of \(x\) apples and \(y\) bananas.
(d) Solve the simultaneous equations.
You must show all your working.
(i) Write down the colour of toy car that Kurt owns most of.
(ii) Find the number of yellow toy cars that Kurt owns.
(iii) Find how many more red toy cars than white toy cars Kurt owns.
5 (a) Kurt owns some toy cars of different colours. The pictogram shows the number of each colour.
Key: \(\square=8\) cars \(\square\)
(b) A toy car costs \(\$ 12.40\) in the USA and 11.50 euros in Spain. The exchange rate is 1 euro \(=\$ 1.12\).
Calculate the difference in the cost of the toy car in euros. Give your answer correct to 2 decimal places.
(c) Leo owns some toy vehicles. He owns 57 cars, 12 bicycles and 42 trucks.
Find the ratio of the number of cars: bicycles: trucks in its simplest form.
(i) The shelf is in the shape of a right-angled triangle.
The area of the shelf is \(0.3 \mathrm{~m}^{2}\).
Calculate the value of \(y\).
(ii) The shelf is 1.35 metres from the floor.
Change 1.35 metres into centimetres.
(d) Leo keeps his toy vehicles on a shelf.
The diagram shows a plan of Zak's garden.
Find the perimeter of the garden.
(i) Which night was coldest?
(ii) Find the difference in temperature between Friday night and Saturday night.
(c) Zak buys pea plants, bean plants and sunflower plants in the ratio peas:beans:sunflowers \(=7:5:2\). He buys 45 bean plants.
Show that the total number of plants he buys is 126.
(b) Zak records the temperature in his garden each night for one week.
Write down the mathematical name for this solid.
(i) Measure the size of angle \(x\).
(ii) Write down the mathematical name for this type of angle.
(i) Give a geometrical reason why angle \(A C B\) is \(90^{\circ}\).
(ii) Calculate the circumference of the circle.
(iii) Show that \(A C\) is 9.8 cm , correct to 2 significant figures.
Points \(A, B\) and \(C\) lie on the circle, centre \(O\). \(A B=11 \mathrm{~cm}\) and \(B C=5 \mathrm{~cm}\).
(d) The surface area of a sphere is \(250 \mathrm{~cm}^{2}\).
Calculate the radius of the sphere.
[The surface area, \(A\), of a sphere with radius \(r\) is \(A=4 \pi r^{2}\).]
8 (a) (i) Complete the table of values for \(y=4 x-x^{2}\).
(ii) On the grid, draw the graph of \(y=4 x-x^{2}\) for \(-1 \leqslant x \leqslant 6\).
(b) The line \(L\) is shown on the grid.
Find the equation of line \(L\).
(a) Write down the mathematical name of shape \(A\).
(b) Describe fully the single transformation that maps shape \(A\) onto shape \(B\).
(c) Describe fully the single transformation that maps shape \(A\) onto shape \(C\).
(d) Draw the image of shape \(A\) after a rotation, \(90^{\circ}\) clockwise, centre \((0,0)\).
(e) Draw the image of shape \(A\) after a reflection in the line \(x=1\).
9 Shapes \(A, B\) and \(C\) are shown on the grid.
